en.Tiejun Huang_1: Huang Tiejun, male, Han ethnicity, was born in November 1970. He holds a Ph.D. and is a professor. He is a professor at the School of Computer Science, Peking University, and the president of Beijing Academy of Artificial Intelligence. His research interests include visual information processing，Brain-Like Large Models and Embodied Intelligence.
en.Tiejun Huang_2: He has won the Second Prize of the National Technological Invention Award (ranked 1 in 2017), the Second Prize of the National Science and Technology Progress Award (ranked 2 in 2012, ranked 4 in 2010). He is a recipient of the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars (2014), a specially-appointed professor of the Changjiang Scholars Program of the Ministry of Education (2015), a leading talent in scientific and technological innovation of the Ten Thousand Talents Program (2018), a fellow of the China Computer Federation (2019), a fellow of the Chinese Association for Artificial Intelligence (2019), and a fellow of the China Society of Image and Graphics (2021).

en.Zhaofei Yu_1: Yu Zhaofei is currently a researcher and doctoral supervisor at the Institute of Artificial Intelligence, Peking University, and a recipient of the National Excellent Young Scientists Fund. He obtained his Bachelor of Engineering degree from Chongqing University in 2012 and his Doctor of Engineering degree from Tsinghua University in 2017. From 2017 to 2020, he conducted postdoctoral research at Peking University. His main research directions are brain-inspired computing and neuromorphic computing. He has published more than 60 papers in top journals such as Nature Biomedical Engineering, Science Advance, IEEE Transactions, and top conferences like NeurIPS, ICLR, ICML, CVPR, ICCV, ECCV, AAAI, and IJCAI. He has presided over sub-projects of major projects of the Ministry of Science and Technology's "Brain Science and Brain-inspired Research", general projects of the National Natural Science Foundation of China, Beijing Science and Technology New Star Program, and the Postdoctoral Innovative Talent Support Program. He serves as the Area Chair of conferences such as ICML, ICLR, and ACM MM, and a Senior PC Member of AAAI. He has won the second prize of the Beijing Science and Technology Award.

en.Ye Chen_1: Ye Chen is a PhD student at the Institute for Artificial Intelligence, Peking University. His research focuses on brain-like visual decoding, analyzing multimodal neural data (fMRI, electrophysiological, and calcium signals) across various species including mice, salamanders, monkeys, and humans using deep learning techniques. He successfully reconstructs natural visual stimuli from key brain regions such as the visual cortex, midbrain, and thalamus. He has published first-author research in PLOS Computational Biology titled "Decoding dynamic visual scenes across the brain hierarchy." He is dedicated to advancing next-generation brain-inspired intelligence and brain-computer interface (BCI) technologies through a deeper understanding of biological visual pathways.

en.projects_intro_1: Our laboratory is deeply engaged in cutting-edge fields such as brain-inspired computing, neuromorphic computing, and spiking neural networks. We are committed to unraveling the mysteries of the brain's information processing and constructing computational paradigms that are closer to biological intelligence.
en.projects_intro_2: Based on in-depth analysis of neurodynamics, we break through the limitations of traditional artificial neural networks, develop low-power consumption and highly parallel spiking neural networks, and explore innovative applications of spike coding mechanisms in real-time perception and autonomous learning.
en.projects_intro_3: Our team integrates neuroscience, computer science, and microelectronics technology, and has achieved a series of results in areas such as brain-inspired cognitive models and dynamic environment adaptation algorithms. These efforts provide core technical support for the new generation of artificial intelligence, edge computing, and brain-computer interfaces, driving the evolution of intelligent systems toward higher efficiency, robustness, and human-like characteristics.
en.edu_comp_neuro_title: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience: From Brain Simulation to NeuroAI
en.edu_comp_neuro_desc: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience: From Brain Simulation to NeuroAI is designed for students and researchers interested in the computational principles of the brain, neural system modeling, and brain-inspired artificial intelligence. The course begins with the biological foundations of neurons and neural circuits, covering electrophysiological models, neural coding theories, and network dynamics. Students will also learn about multiscale brain modeling and brain simulation, gaining insight into computation from single neurons to large-scale brain systems. Building on these foundations, the course explores recent advances in NeuroAI, including brain-inspired machine learning models, neuromorphic computing, training mechanisms for brain-like networks, and emerging directions that integrate large AI models with neuroscience. Through hands-on experiments, simulations, and small research projects, students will acquire both theoretical understanding and practical skills, developing the ability to apply neuroscience insights to intelligent algorithm design.
en.edu_num_anal_desc: Numerical Analysis is a fundamental course focusing on computational techniques for solving mathematical problems under finite-precision conditions. The course covers error analysis, interpolation and approximation, numerical differentiation and integration, numerical solutions of linear and nonlinear equations, numerical methods for ordinary differential equations, eigenvalue problems, and basic numerical optimization methods. Through a combination of theoretical instruction and programming practice, students learn how to design and analyze numerical algorithms, understand key concepts such as stability, convergence, and complexity, and apply numerical methods to scientific computing, engineering simulation, and data analysis. This course is essential for students in mathematics, computer science, and engineering, serving as a foundation for advanced study in scientific and high-performance computing.
en.edu_bcc_desc: Brain, Cognition, and Computation is an interdisciplinary course designed for students interested in the intersection of neuroscience, cognitive science, and computational methods. The course begins with an overview of brain structures and functions, covering the neural mechanisms underlying perception, attention, memory, learning, and decision-making, as well as the fundamental principles of human intelligence. Building on this foundation, the course introduces computational approaches such as neural network models, Bayesian cognitive models, connectionism, and brain-inspired computational frameworks. Students learn how computational modeling helps explain cognitive processes and how biological and cognitive principles can inspire the development of intelligent algorithms. Through hands-on experiments, behavioral studies, and model implementation, students gain a systematic understanding of the relationships among the brain, cognition, and computation and develop the foundational skills needed for research in cognitive science and AI.
en.edu_frontier_desc: Frontier Computing Research Practice is designed for advanced undergraduates and graduate students interested in cutting-edge technology in artificial intelligence and computing, the course explores emerging trends in the field, including brain-inspired intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, neuromorphic computing, and intelligent system architectures. Emphasizing research practice, the course adopts a problem-driven and project-based approach, helping students understand the theoretical foundations, key technologies, and future directions of AI. Through hands-on experiments and mini research projects, students develop practical skills and scientific research thinking. The course aims to cultivate innovation capability and prepare students to engage with leading-edge research in frontier computing.
en.edu_llm_title: Large Language Models: From Fundamentals to Practice
en.edu_llm_desc: Large Language Models: From Fundamentals to Practice is designed for learners aiming to master both the theoretical foundations and practical application of large language models (LLMs). The course covers essential concepts such as model architectures, training paradigms, inference mechanisms, and safety alignment, while also exploring real-world applications in text, image, speech, and multimodal domains. Combining theory with hands-on practice, the course guides students through fine-tuning LLMs, building datasets, developing applications, and optimizing deployment, enabling them to understand the full workflow from model construction to real-world implementation. This course is ideal for students and developers in artificial intelligence, computer science, and related fields.
en.edu_dmt_desc: Digital Media Technology is a comprehensive course that introduces the principles and applications of digital content creation, processing, presentation, and interaction. The course covers key areas such as digital image processing, audio and video coding, interaction design, and multimedia systems. By combining theoretical instruction with hands-on projects, students learn the full workflow of digital media technologies—from content acquisition, editing, compression, and transmission to visualization, interaction, and application development. The course emphasizes innovation and practical skills, making it suitable for students pursuing fields such as digital media, computer vision, game development, and human-computer interaction. The goal of the course is to provide students with a solid and systematic understanding of digital media technologies and to equip them with the ability to innovate and practice in emerging media, intelligent media, and immersive applications.
en.edu_ml_desc: Machine Learning introduces core concepts such as supervised and unsupervised learning, model evaluation, and practical optimization. Students will experiment with classic models (logistic regression, SVMs, decision trees) and modern deep learning workflows, learning how to prepare data, train, validate, and deploy models in simple applications.

zh.projects_intro_1: 我们的实验室深耕于脑启发计算、神经形态计算以及脉冲神经网络等前沿领域，致力于揭示大脑信息处理的机理，并构建更接近生物智能的计算范式。
zh.projects_intro_2: 基于对神经动力学的深入分析，我们突破传统人工神经网络的限制，发展低功耗且高度并行的脉冲神经网络，并探索脉冲编码机制在实时感知与自主学习中的创新应用。
zh.projects_intro_3: 我们团队融合神经科学、计算机科学与微电子技术，在脑启发认知模型与动态环境适应算法等方面取得了一系列成果。这些成果为新一代人工智能、边缘计算与脑机接口等领域提供了核心技术支撑，推动智能系统向更高效、更稳健、更具人性化特征的方向演进。
zh.edu_comp_neuro_title: 计算神经科学导论：从大脑模拟到NeuroAI
zh.edu_comp_neuro_desc: 《计算神经科学导论：从大脑模拟到 NeuroAI》面向对大脑计算原理、神经系统建模以及类脑人工智能感兴趣的学生与研究者。课程从神经元与神经网络的生物基础出发，介绍电生理模型、神经编码理论、网络动力学等计算神经科学核心内容，并逐步引入大脑模拟及多尺度建模方法，帮助学生理解从单个神经元到大脑系统的计算过程。在此基础上，课程进一步探讨 NeuroAI 的最新进展，包括脑启发机器学习模型、神经形态计算、类脑网络训练机制以及大模型与神经科学融合的新趋势。通过实验、仿真与简易研究项目，学生将获得理论理解与实践能力，初步具备将脑科学知识应用于智能算法研究的能力。
zh.edu_num_anal_desc: 《数值分析》是一门研究利用计算方法求解数学问题的基础课程，主要关注在有限精度条件下如何设计高效、稳定且精确的算法。课程内容包括误差分析、插值与逼近、数值积分与微分、线性方程组的数值解、非线性方程求解、常微分方程数值方法、特征值问题以及优化的基本数值方法等。通过理论讲解与编程实践相结合，学生将掌握构建和分析数值算法的基本思想，理解算法稳定性、收敛性与复杂度等关键问题，并能够将数值方法应用于科学计算、工程模拟和数据分析等实际场景。课程适合数学、计算机、工程类专业学生，是后续进行科学计算和高性能计算研究的重要基础。
zh.edu_bcc_desc: 《脑、认知与计算》是一门跨学科课程，面向对脑科学、认知科学与计算方法交叉领域感兴趣的学生。课程从大脑结构与功能入手，介绍知觉、注意、记忆、学习、决策等核心认知过程的神经机制，并讨论人类智能的基本原理。 在此基础上，课程引入计算建模方法，包括神经网络模型、贝叶斯认知模型、连接主义及类脑计算框架，探讨如何利用计算方法理解认知机制，以及如何从生物和认知启发中设计新型智能算法。通过小型实验、行为研究与模型实现，学生将获得对脑、认知和计算之间关系的系统认识，具备在认知科学与人工智能交叉领域开展研究的基础能力。
zh.edu_frontier_desc: 《前沿计算研究实践》面向对人工智能与计算前沿技术感兴趣的高年级本科生及研究生。课程围绕当前计算技术的最新趋势，涵盖类脑智能、机器学习、深度学习、神经形态计算、智能系统架构等领域前沿。教学方式以科研实践为核心，强调问题导向与项目驱动，引导学生理解人工智能发展的理论基础、关键技术与未来方向，并通过实验和小型研究任务获得动手能力与科研思维训练。课程目标是帮助学生理解前沿计算技术的研究方法，培养综合创新能力，逐步具备进入科研前沿领域的潜力。
zh.edu_llm_desc: 《大模型：从基础到实战》面向希望系统掌握大规模预训练模型（Large Language Models, LLMs）原理与应用的学习者。课程内容覆盖大模型的基础理论、核心算法、训练方法、推理机制及安全对齐技术，并深入讲解大模型在文本、图像、语音、多模态等领域的具体应用。课程强调理论与实践结合，学生将通过实操完成大模型微调、数据构建、应用开发和部署优化等任务，全面理解从模型构建到真实场景落地的完整流程。本课程适合人工智能、计算机科学及相关领域的学生及开发者。
zh.edu_dmt_desc: 《数字媒体技术》是一门系统介绍数字内容生产、处理、呈现与交互技术的综合性课程。课程涵盖数字图像处理、音视频编码、交互设计、多媒体系统等核心领域。通过理论讲授与实践项目相结合，学生将掌握从数字媒体内容采集、编辑、压缩、传输，到可视化、交互和应用开发的完整技术链。课程强调创新应用与实际动手能力，适合从事数字媒体、计算机视觉、游戏开发、人机交互等方向的学生。本课程旨在帮助学生建立数字媒体技术的系统知识框架，并具备在新媒体、智能媒体与沉浸式应用领域开展实践与创新的能力。
zh.edu_ml_desc: 《机器学习》介绍监督与无监督学习的核心概念、模型评估以及实用优化。学生将通过实践体验经典模型（逻辑回归、支持向量机、决策树）和现代深度学习流程，学习如何准备数据、训练、验证并在简易场景中部署模型。
